message: Happy New Year!   I hope you all had a wonderful and safe time celebrating. Looking ahead to 2017, I am thrilled by the opportunity to continue to serve Eastern Kansans in Congress and work with my colleagues to create an opportunity economy, reform our broken tax code and help get more Americans back to work!

Today is the start of the 115th Congress. I am honored and blessed to once again serve the great people of Eastern Kansas in Congress. We will hit the ground running this Congress, moving forward with an agenda focused on job creation and making government work for the American people. I will continue to focus on issues such as healthcare, education and tax reform, looking to build a stronger opportunity economy that enables all Americans to succeed. As always, I am here to represent Kansans and I look forward to bringing some Kansas commonsense to Washington, DC.

Israel is America’s great ally and friend. For decades the US has stood by our strategic partner against the one-sided resolutions of the UN. By choosing to abstain on the recent Security Council resolution, President Obama jeopardizes the peace process and risks America’s key relationship with Israel simply to make an incomprehensible ideological point.   Today, I voted for H. Res. 11 which expresses the House’s strong, bipartisan disapproval of the resolution and let’s Israel know that America still stands with them. Some things may be up for debate, but the importance and depth of America’s friendship with Israel should never be questioned.
NA

The truth is that, while the Affordable Care Act may have come from a place of trying to help people, it has failed too many others. Regulations contained within the law have increased costs and obstacles for folks simply trying to get better. I wrote today in the Washington Examiner about what we need to change, and what I am doing to help ensure our healthcare system always puts the patients first.
Growing up on a dairy farm in Holton, Kansas, I have a love for all things dairy – mainly ice cream and milkshakes. Cheers to #NationalMilkDay and to the dairy farmers who produce it!
Best of luck to Congressman Mike Pompeo today! I know that he will make all Kansans proud! If you are interested in watching the confirmation hearing, tune in below.

Today, I joined my House colleagues in taking the first step in repealing the President’s flawed healthcare law and transitioning to a patient-centered healthcare system. While we have many more steps ahead, I will continue to listen to Kansans and ensure their thoughts on a better healthcare system are heard in Congress – such as allowing dependents to stay on their parent's healthcare plan until the age of 26. Additionally, I believe it is important that we have a replacement plan that is concurrent with a repeal of Obamacare. I look forward to working with my colleagues to create a more patient-centered healthcare solution that puts the control of their own healthcare back in the hands of the American people.
Are you ready for The Kansas City Chiefs game tonight?! Any predictions? I predict the Chiefs win 24-17. #Chiefskingdom
"Faith is taking the first step even when you don't see the whole staircase."  Please join me in honoring and celebrating the life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

As a mother of two, I understand, first-hand, how important it is to start saving for our children’s education. That’s why I, along with Congressman Kind, introduced a bill to expand 529 plans and allow hard-working families to better plan ahead for the high costs of college. This bill will improve the program by encouraging employers to contribute to 529 plans and removing penalties for using the funds to pay for loans. This bipartisan, commonsense bill will continue to strengthen 529 plans, an increasingly popular college savings plan, so all students will have the opportunity to continue their education and achieve their dreams.

With all the talk from the White House in recent weeks about respecting the intelligence community, I find it ironic the President chose to commute Chelsea Manning’s sentence. The President chose a lawbreaker who compromised our national security over the men and women in the intelligence community, setting a dangerous precedent.

I had a blast hanging out with the Ottawa Fire Department this week! The men and women with the Ottawa Fire Department have been working tirelessly to ensure the safety of the Ottawa community for 150 years. It was my honor to present them with a certificate and an American flag, that had been flown over the U.S. Capitol, to commemorate their many years of service. After our ceremony, the firefighters got me set up in their equipment and told me about many of their local fire initiatives. Thanks to the Ottawa Fire Department for having me, and congratulations on 150 years of service.

The peaceful transition of power from one President to another is a bedrock principle of our system of government. I congratulate our new President and, with a unified Republican government, I look forward to working with President Trump to get America back on the right track – by reforming our broken tax code, replacing Obamacare with a more patient-center healthcare system and growing our economy.

ATTENTION: My office is currently in the process of launching a new website. During this process, we have been told that there may be a few technical difficulties. However, these difficulties should only last for roughly 24 hours. If you need any assistance in the meantime, please feel free to call my offices in Kansas or Washington, DC:  Topeka: (785) 234-5966 Pittsburg: (620) 231-5966 Washington, DC:  (202) 225-6601

At a critical time for our nation’s intelligence services, I can think of few people as qualified and capable of leading the CIA than Mike Pompeo. As someone I have been proud to know for years and to serve with in Congress for the past six years, I wish all the best to Mike and his family on this new adventure. I know he will make Kansans proud.
Every student deserves access to quality education, regardless of zip code. Happy #NationalSchoolChoiceWeek!
At the end of this term, I will be retiring from public service. There is a lot more work to be done so let’s finish strong!

Recently, I introduced legislation that would protect hospital based-nursing programs across the United States as they face conflicting regulatory requirements from Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) and their accreditation bodies. This bipartisan, sensible legislation is critical for the future of our healthcare workforce and I look forward to working with my colleagues to quickly pass this bill in the House. Click below for more information on the MEND Act.
Happy Kansas Day! As a sixth generation Kansan, I am proud to wish a Happy 156th Birthday to the beautiful Sunflower State. Be sure to check out the The Library of Congress' Kansas collection today!

With Obamacare’s skyrocketing health premiums, quickly multiplying deductibles, and diminishing providers, it is clear that we need a patient-centered healthcare system.   To read the editorial I wrote with Congressman Kevin Yoder and Congressman Roger Marshall, M.D. for The Kansas City Star about how we can fix our broken healthcare system, follow the link below.

Recently, I introduced a bill that will permanently extend the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services’ (CMS) enforcement moratorium on its “direct supervision” rule for outpatient therapeutic services provided in Critical Access Hospitals and small, rural hospitals with 100 or fewer beds. I look forward to working with my colleagues to – once again – get this bipartisan bill to the President’s desk and ensure all Americans, no matter where you live, receive quality care in a timely manner. Click the link below if you would like to learn more about my latest bill.

It has been a busy week in Washington meeting with Kansas bankers, wheat growers, prosecutors, our Kansas Insurance Commissioner, and many more! Thank you to everyone for stopping by, I always enjoy listening to your insights and sharing them with my colleagues.

Iran is one of the leading state-sponsors of terrorism. They have continuously violated the UN resolutions regarding ballistic missile tests. I fully support the Trump administration’s new sanctions on Iran – we must hold them accountable.
So great to see President Bush and Mrs. Bush do the coin toss at the Super Bowl!

My latest bipartisan bill with Rep. Ron Kind (D-WI) will help make it easier for families to save and pay for college. To learn more about how my legislation will help students off-set the cost of college, click below:

Recently, I introduced H.R. 721, BRACE Act. This legislation will extend the Section 45G (26 USC 45G) short line track maintenance tax credit that expired at the end of 2016. Our short line railroads connect farmers, ranchers, and businesses across eastern Kansas with the rest of the nation. By investing in rail infrastructure, we can directly boost our local economies and increase business competitiveness. This bipartisan legislation will allow for major track redevelopment and rail improvements, along with putting Americans to work and expanding competitively priced rail service. I look forward to working with my House colleagues to ensure the success of this commonsense program.

This week, I had a great time meeting with folks from all across the state of Kansas. Discussing everything from rural water programs, to benefiting small business owners, to advancing higher education, I had so many productive conversations about how I can best continue to serve the people of Eastern Kansas.
Coach Bill Snyder is one of the toughest guys I know. Please join me in praying for Coach Snyder and his family. See you on the field soon!

I am proud to have the support of the College Savings Plans Network for my 529 bill, which will make it easier for families to save for college, and help students tackle the cost of higher education. This legislation will help ensure that kids dreaming of attending college are able to pursue their degree.

Obamacare is simply unsustainable. In the words Aetna CEO Mark Bertolini: “It’s not going to get any better; it’s getting worse.” Now is the time to fix our broken healthcare system, and I look forward to working with my colleagues to create a more patient-centered solution.

This week, I met with Special Olympian Rylee Robinson, Prairie Band Potawatomi Chairwoman Liana Onnen, and the great folks from Freedom’s Frontier. Thank you to everyone for your valuable thoughts and insights on how I can continue to best serve Eastern Kansans.
Happy Presidents’ Day! Today, we celebrate the presidential leadership our country has seen since our nation’s birth and the presidency of George Washington.

I am honored to be named the Rural Health Legislator of the Year by the National Organization of State Offices of Rural Health! I will continue to work to help provide quality healthcare for all rural Kansans.

I introduced H.R. 394 – Restoring Access to Medication Act of 2017, to help put Americans back in charge of their own healthcare expenses. I am thankful to have the support of the Consumer Healthcare Products Association (CHPA). Read this editorial below to learn more about my bipartisan bill.

Today the Trump administration ordered a reverse in the Environment Protection Agency’s vastly overreaching Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule. The rule would illegitimately add thousands of private bodies of water—from farm ditches to dry creek beds—to the definition of what the government can regulate. The EPA was not authorized to make such a wide-ranging power grab and these types of wide policy changes should only be considered in Congress through the legislative process, not issued by agency mandates. Simply put, government bureaucrats should not be writing de facto laws that unnecessarily increase the cost on farmers and ranchers, especially when such proposals have been so strongly rejected by Congress. I applaud the administration in taking the necessary steps to reverse this greatly misguided regulation.

Tonight, I was pleased to hear President Trump’s call to reform our broken tax code during his address to Congress. All across Eastern Kansas, folks have expressed their interest in making our tax code much simpler and fairer. That’s why, as a member of the Ways and Means Committee, I am working with my colleagues to reform our tax code and make it much simpler. I look forward to working with the Administration to help fix our tax code to make it fairer, simpler and painless.
Happy #WomensHistoryMonth! This March, we pay tribute to the trailblazers and brave women who paved the way for generations to come.
I had a great week meeting with our veterans, sitting down the Fragile X Foundation, speaking to Meals on Wheels on behalf of the House Hunger Caucus, and much more!

There has been a lot of severe weather in Kansas and my prayers are with those who have been affected by these storms. It is very important that we are prepared for severe weather. That's why today there will be a state-wide tornado drill as part of Severe Weather Awareness Week. Read the article below for more information.

I have always advocated for a patient-centered healthcare system in order to put healthcare back in the hands of the American people. I am pleased to see that this proposed healthcare legislation is a step in that direction. It also makes good on my commitment to help those with pre-existing conditions, ban annual and lifetime caps, and allow dependents to stay on their parent's healthcare plan until the age of 26. As I review this legislation, and it moves through an open and transparent legislative process, I appreciate any and all feedback from Kansans so I can ensure their voices are heard in Congress.

Roughly seven years ago, Republicans pledged to provide a patient-centered solution to our healthcare system. Early this morning, in the Ways and Means Committee room, I took another step in fulfilling that promise. This important healthcare legislation will continue to help those with pre-existing conditions, ban annual and lifetime caps, and allow dependents to stay on their parent's healthcare plan until the age of 26 while repealing Obamacare’s penalizing mandates and taxes. Additionally, this bill contains provisions, which I authored, that will allow plan participants to use the funds in their Health Savings Account and Flexible Spending Account to purchase over-the-counter medications. As the American Health Care Act makes its way to the House Floor, in an open and transparent process, I value any and all feedback from folks in Kansas so that their voices are heard in Congress.

Thank you to everyone who was able to attend my listening session in Lawrence today. While we may not agree on everything, I always appreciate you taking the time out of your day to meet and speak with me.

One of most important tenets of being a member of Congress is listening to the people you represent whether they live in Lawrence, Highland, or Fredonia. That was the exact reason for my listening session in Lawrence on Monday. But, as the Lawrence Journal World’s latest editorial about me accurately points out, I represent more than just the several hundred vocal constituents that attended my recent town hall. While many of them supported countervailing opinions, I still have a responsibility to represent the Second District at large.     The 25 counties in that district are very diverse ideologically. That means voting directly against the preferences of some Kansans every single day, but that does not mean I am not listening. I was elected to office with about 60% of the vote on average by running, in part, on the promise to repeal Obamacare and replace it with a patient-centered solution to our healthcare system. I intend to keep my word.   While this bill is far from perfect, I think the foundation of the American Health Care Act – the first of our 3 step process – is a step in the right direction. I believe it will be amended and improved upon before it becomes law.    As for other parts of the Lawrence Journal World editorial, I could not disagree more. While the sub-headline of this editorial calls for more honesty, honesty should be a two way street.   What the editorial failed to mention is that I took the stage of the Dole Institute around 3:25pm, roughly 10 minutes after the Congressional Budget Office released their report, and fewer than that by the time I received it. I was in the car and there was no way for me to completely review this report in a couple minutes before heading on stage. I knew only the bare basics.    But now that I have had the time to review the CBO’s score, I noticed that the editorial omitted several key facts. They failed to mention that the CBO stated the American Health Care Act will lower premiums by 10 percent. They failed to mention that the CBO stated the American Health Care Act will reduced the federal deficit by $337 billion. They failed to mention that the CBO stated the American Health Care Act will lower taxes by $883 billion. They failed to mention that the CBO stated the American Health Care Act will increase choices for consumers – especially important since insurers, like Humana, are leaving Obamacare’s insurance exchanges. They failed to mention that the primary reason why fewer people will be covered as currently drafted, is because the new bill makes it legal to choose to be insured or to not be insured. And, yes, they failed to mention that the CBO is fallible as was proven out by their coverage projections for Obamacare   As I said earlier, this bill is far from perfect and is a work in progress. I represent 25 counties in Kansas’ 2nd Congressional District, filled with many different views. These listening tours are a way for me to connect with those I represent and ensure their voices are heard in Congress. I appreciate everyone for joining my listening sessions and telephone town halls along the way, I will be sure to update you as this bill moves through Congress.
"Wherever you go and whatever you do, may the luck of the Irish be there with you."  Happy Saint Patrick's Day!

“Women who stepped up were measured as citizens of the nation, not as women...This was a people's war, and everyone was in it.”—Oveta Culp Hobby  I am proud to be a cosponsor of H.Res.162, a bipartisan resolution that expresses support for designating today, March 21, 2017, as “National Rosie the Riveter Day.” These tenacious “Rosies” rolled up their sleeves and helped build engines, planes, tanks, and served our nation during one of its darkest times. I am proud to honor these hundreds of thousands of women who challenged traditional gender roles and went to work to aid the war effort. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-rosie-pix-idUSKBN16S10M

Last week, Time Magazine’s Money division highlighted my bipartisan 529 bill to expand and improve 529 and ABLE accounts when saving and paying for college. This legislation will help raise awareness for these college savings plans, it will encourage employers to add 529 plans to their benefits package, and it will expand the ways in which 529 and ABLE accounts may be used.
Great article remembering the countless accomplishments of President, General, and Kansan Dwight D. Eisenhower.

I had a great time touring the Price Chopper store in Bonner Springs and visiting Best Buy in Lawrence. It is always helpful to meet retailers around the Second District, and I thank Price Chopper and Best Buy for having me today.

"Imagine a world where 529 plans — tax-advantaged accounts that help make it easier for parents or other family members to save for a child's future college costs — were a standard part of your job benefits package.  Sound like a pipe dream? Not if two bills introduced into Congress this year get passed into law."  For more information, check out this Forbes article on my legislation, the 529 and ABLE Account Improvement Act below.

It was great to testify before the House Agriculture Committee on how tax reform will help the agriculture economy and rural way of life.  I was raised on a dairy farm in Holton and I can speak with firsthand knowledge about the challenges and rewards that come with farming. Ours was a family operation, not at all different from any other small business. And as such, we had to balance work on the farm with the complicated bookkeeping that goes along with it.    To make life easier for American families and businesses, the Ways and Means Committee has embarked on an effort to accomplish comprehensive tax reform for the first time since 1986. The guiding principles of tax reform will be beneficial to the agriculture community.

Recently, I introduced H.R. 1828, the Rural Access to Hospice Act. This legislation will correct a barrier in the Medicare system and grant more access to more Americans and save the Medicare system money.  Many Americans wish to receive care in the comfortable setting of a hospice care center, in communication with their doctor of many years. The Rural Access to Hospice Act will allow those people to do that, and help them get quality, affordable care closer to home.

The recent chemical attack by Bashar al-Assad was heinous. I applaud President Trump's swift and decisive action to show that America will no longer stand on the sideline as innocent men, women, and babies are brutally killed in Syria. In the coming weeks, I urge President Trump to work with Congress to develop a clear and comprehensive strategy for Syria and the surrounding region.
Congratulations to Justice Neil Gorsuch! Great to have a Justice that respects the rule of law and ardently defends the Constitution.

Thank you to BNSF Railway for showing me around their Topeka office location on Monday. I appreciated having the opportunity to meet and speak with them about several issues, such as railroad retirement.
Loved chatting with seniors at Topeka West High School about what's been happening in Congress. Congratulations to them on their upcoming graduation!
Happy Easter to everyone who is celebrating today. Hallelujah!

"Small towns have their problems. Isolation. Poverty. Lack of opportunity.  But when it comes to charity and giving and helping your neighbors, the vast majority of people in small towns understand if you want anything done around here, it’s all hands on deck."

Our tax code is broken. It does not work for the American people, but rather the American people must spend time and money jumping through many hoops and regulations. That’s why Ways and Means is working to reform our crippled system: create a tax code that grows jobs and wages, reform the IRS, and make filing taxes as simple as filling out a post card.

Thank you to the Southeast Kansas Community Action Program (SEK-CAP) Head Start in Chanute for inviting me to visit! I loved the opportunity to meet the kids and hear from staff. Early childhood education programs, like Head Start, make such a positive difference for our kids in Kansas. http://www.chanute.com/news/article_9339bed4-2492-11e7-8ec0-9736cda2cbac.html

Secretary Sonny Perdue understands rural America and will be a strong voice for Kansas farmers, producers and the agriculture community. I look forward to working with him on strengthening the farm economy.

Last night, I was pleased to introduce Congressman Ron Estes on the House floor. I have known Ron, and his wife Susan, for many years. He is truly one of the nicest guys you would ever want to know. Watch my full remarks below.

For far too long, mental health illness has been buried beneath stigmatization.  This May, I am proud to be a part of the dialogue surrounding mental health in America. I stand steadfastly alongside the millions affected each year, and I pledge to continue championing this cause. Please join me in honoring Mental Health Awareness Month this May as we work to end the stigma and break the silence for good.

Today, I spoke on the House Floor in support of the Working Families Flexibility Act which directly benefits worker and their families.  For hourly workers, having the voluntary option to take either money or more time with your family opens up a world of possibilities for folks to spend more time with their kids, run errands or make appointments. This is an option provided to workers in the public sector – why wouldn’t we want to give this option to all American workers?   Please watch my full remarks below.

It’s no secret that the Affordable Care Act is collapsing under its own weight. According to media reports, only one-third of counties in the United States have one insurer in the Obamacare marketplace. Kansans deserve a better healthcare system, one that is patient-centered and creates competition to drive down the high cost of medical needs.   To that end, I have been working with my House colleagues to create a much more affordable healthcare system. While the American Health Care Act is not perfect, it is another step in offering Kansans more choices and freedoms by repealing penalizing taxes and regulations – encouraging insurers to stay in their respective markets and enter new markets.    As for those with pre-existing conditions, the AHCA specifically states, that it will not limit access to coverage for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Thus, legally, insurance companies cannot deny folks coverage based on pre-existing conditions.    Most importantly, in states who do not seek a waiver, health insurers will not be allowed to charge higher premiums due to pre-existing conditions. In states that ask for and receive a waiver, folks who have been continuously covered for one year, and do not go without coverage for more than 63 days, will not be charged higher premiums due to their preexisting conditions. The bottom-line is that if you stay covered, you cannot be charged more under the law.    The current healthcare system is not working – as noted by the countless Kansans who have called, emailed, written and met with me since Obamacare went online in 2013. While this legislation is a start, it is far from reaching the President’s desk, and in the coming weeks, I will continue to listen to your thoughts regarding this important issue and share them with my colleagues to ensure they are heard in Congress.  Items to Note:  - House Republicans included an extra $8 billion dedicated to lowering premiums or other out-of-pocket expenses on top of the $130 billion available to states through the AHCA’s Patient and State Stability Fund.  - In Kansas, the AHCA will close the coverage gap for the 50,000 folks just above Medicaid eligibility who did not receive tax subsidies. - Once the American Health Care Act is fully implemented in 2020, premiums will begin to decrease – allowing families and individuals to save money. - Lastly, the American Health Care Act includes Congresswoman Jenkins’ language, from the Restoring Access to Medication Act, to allow individuals and families to use the funds in their Health Savings Account and Flexible Spending Account to purchase over-the-counter medications.

It was great visiting Forbes Field Air National Guard Base today for a briefing and tour of the KC-135 Stratotanker. Thank you to all of our brave men and women in uniform for your service to our country. We greatly appreciate it!

The President has every legal authority to remove the Director of the FBI. However, the timing of this removal is concerning and raises questions that need to be answered as there are too many conflicting reports within the Administration. In regard to the Russian inquiry, I have full faith in the men and women of the FBI, along with those in the House and Senate Intelligence Committee, to continue to perform their investigative duties. They are some of our nation’s best and brightest and are true professionals. It is my hope that the next FBI Director will be a strong independent voice, who continues the legacy of the FBI as being one of the top intelligence agencies in the world.

I always love any opportunity I have to visit The University of Kansas' campus. On Thursday, Director of Corporate and Community Engagement David Byrd-Stadler took me around the Capitol Federal Business School and showed me the beautiful building. Thank you to the faculty at KU for the tour, and congratulations to this year’s graduating seniors! Rock Chalk!

Happy #MothersDay to all my fellow moms out there! I am beyond fortunate to have such a thoughtful, caring, and kind mother. Today, and everyday, be sure to tell your momma how much you appreciate and love her.

On May 17, 1954, the Supreme Court handed down its landmark ruling on Brown v. Board of Education, declaring ‘separate but equal’ is inherently unequal. With this decision, the Brown family of Topeka partnered with other families to forever change the United States. We are forever indebted to them for their willingness to stand up for justice, and fulfill the promise of the abolitionist founding of our great state. Today, please join me in celebrating the 63rd anniversary of this historic Supreme Court decision.

As the former FBI Director in both President Bush and President Obama’s administrations, Robert Mueller has earned support from both sides of the aisle in Congress. I welcome the Department of Justice’s decision to add Robert Mueller as special counsel to their investigation. With an investigation in the House, Senate, and Department of Justice underway, I believe now is the time to return our focus to helping Americans by reforming our tax code and getting more folks back to work.

The cowardly attack on the innocent lives at the Manchester Arena last night is heinous. Some of the victims were teens and kids. The United Kingdom has been a critical ally and component on the war on terror. America will continue to stand with our United Kingdom friends and help bring justice for the victims and their families.

This Memorial Day, please join me in honoring all the U.S. military men and women who answered the ultimate call of duty in protecting our freedoms and liberties. These courageous servicemen and women laid down their lives to defend our freedom, and each American owes them an unbelievable debt. We will never forget this greatest sacrifice.

This week in Washington, I had the privilege of speaking with many Kansans about upcoming legislation in Congress. While speaking to the American Institute of CPAs, I gave an update on the Ways and Means Committee work to repair our broken tax code. Later, I discussed the importance of Farm Bill programs with the Kansas Farm Bureau, and postal delivery standards with the National Rural Letter Carriers Association. Lastly, I heard from the American Academy of Family Physicians about the status of healthcare in Kansas, and what we can do to ensure that Kansas physicians are able to provide the best care to their patients. Thank you to everyone for sharing with me their thoughts and insights!

For millennials and future generations to come, 529 college savings plans and ABLE accounts could make a significant difference when it comes to tackling education expenses. To learn more about my bipartisan bill that will help expand and improve these tax-free higher education savings accounts, read my op-ed in the Topeka Capital Journal here: http://cjonline.com/opinion/columns/2017-05-28/lynn-jenkins-helping-millennials-pay-school

As a CPA, I see the need to make bookkeeping easier for American families and businesses. The Committee on Ways and Means has embarked on an effort to streamline the tax code for the first time since 1986. Watch the video below to learn more about our efforts.
Got a sweet tour of the Mars Topeka factory on Wednesday to check out two of my favorite things - peanut M&Ms and their brand new caramel M&Ms!

"The eyes of the world are upon you. The hopes and prayers of liberty-loving people everywhere march with you." - Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower  On June 6, 1944, Allied troops landed in Normandy, France to carry out Operation Overlord, otherwise known as D-Day. 73 years after this historic day, we remember the heroism and sacrifices these soldiers made on the beaches of Normandy.

This morning, I was blessed to meet and greet so many Kansas veterans at the World War II Memorial in Washington, D.C. I am grateful to these veterans for their service to our nation, and thankful for the opportunity to know these great Kansans.
It was a great week meeting with the North Tecumseh Boys & Girls Club, Afterschool Alliance, and the young women from the Sunflower Girls State leadership program!

Earlier this year, I introduced H.R. 741, the Rural Hospital Regulatory Relief Act to prevent Medicare’s enforcement of unreasonable and inflexible direct supervision rules for outpatient therapy services at Critical Access Hospitals and other small, rural hospitals. Read more about how Congress is working to help Critical Access Hospitals and small hospitals in the article below.

For many years, rural hospitals and clinics have suffered from a shortage of anesthesiologists to care for their patients. Attracting physicians to live and work in a rural setting is a unique challenge these critical access hospitals face. My latest bill, the Medicare Access to Rural Anesthesiology Act, remedies this problem by allowing certain rural hospitals to use Medicare Part A funds on a ‘pass-through’ basis. This legislation will make it easier for critical access hospitals to attract and retain physician anesthesiologists to serve their rural communities. Read more about my latest bill with Rep. Emanuel Cleaver II below.

My prayers go out to Congressman Steve Scalise and his family, my Republican colleagues, staffers, and our Capitol police officers involved in this morning’s shooting. Thank you to our first-responders for securing the area and keeping others safe.

Our veterans deserve the most effective, comprehensive care available. This week, the House of Representatives passed the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act with overwhelming bipartisan support, and now the bill will go to the President’s desk to be signed into law. This legislation will protect whistleblowers within the VA, and make it easier to fire federal employees who are failing to provide our vets with satisfactory care. I am proud to support this bill, and I look forward to seeing it signed into law.  http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/house-sends-va-accountability-bill-president-trump-n771871

Happy Father’s Day to all the wonderful dads out there! I grew up with one of the most amazing people in the world – who taught me good values that guide me to this day. Thank you to every one of those fathers out there who, like my dad, devote each day to your children.
Last week I met with German exchange students Atonia & Pauline. Their favorite things about Kansas: the sunsets and their classmates!

You can 'B positive' that Congressman Steve Scalise is a fighter, and on the road to recovery! Thank you to the American Red Cross for this successful blood drive in honor of Rep. Scalise, Matt Mika, and all those injured in last week’s attack.

BREAKING NEWS -- President Trump just signed the VA Accountability Act into law.   This bipartisan legislation will help change the culture of the VA and ensure our veterans receive the care they were promised, earned and deserve. Read more about this bill below.

Last week, the Committee on Ways and Means hosted a hearing on U.S. trade policy with United States Trade Representative (USTR) Robert Lighthizer. At this hearing, I stated that national security should unquestionably be the priority of any government, but I worry that using national security as the basis for trade restrictions in NAFTA, or elsewhere, could backfire if other countries do the same to us. So I asked USTR Lighthizer what argument would he make to a country that tries to restrict its imports of U.S. wheat or other products for food security reasons? Additionally, I asked him what his views are on how NAFTA renegotiation can serve as blueprint for securing future trade deals—which would mean the inclusion of strong SPS provisions that will help Kanas producers gain access to new markets? Watch my questioning below.

Today, my bill (H.R. 1541) to authorize the donation of the Fort Scott, Kan., Civil War era blockhouse known as Lunette Blair to the National Park Service at the Fort Scott National Historic Site passed the House Natural Resources Committee and is now headed to the House floor. This is a great step forward and I am honored to help the Fort Scott community preserve the Lunette Blair blockhouse’s historical legacy.

I am pleased to see the administration continues to reverse the flawed Waters of the United States (WOTUS) rule. The previous administration’s WOTUS rule would have arbitrarily added thousands of private bodies of water to the definition of what the federal government can regulate – which is why it was blocked in federal court in 2015. As the Environmental Protection Agency begins writing a new, common-sensed rule, I will be sure to express Kansans’ thoughts on this issue with the Trump Administration. It is important that we protect our water quality and recognize positive local conservation efforts without taking away folks’ control of their own livelihoods.

This afternoon, I went on CNN with Wolf Blitzer to discuss why the President's recent tweet was not okay. In our debates in Washington, and in dining rooms across the nation, we should debate and when we disagree on matters of public policy; we should do so agreeably with the knowledge in mind that we are all Americans and on the same “team” when it comes to moving our nation forward. This is what we do in Congress: find common ground and move forward.

Happy Fourth of July! May your Independence Day be full of sunshine, lemonade, grilling, parades, fireworks (be safe!), and celebrating our many freedoms as Americans. From my family to yours, have a happy Fourth of July.

I enjoyed getting a tour of St. Francis Health yesterday. It was great to get an update on the hospital and get more information on how we can continue to make them a success. Thank you for the great tour!

At present, there are approximately 3,200 Kansans on dialysis. Dialysis centers specialize in the removal of water and waste from the blood of people with diminished or lost kidney function. So to say that dialysis patients need these centers to survive is not an overstatement. And yet, the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) classifies the inspection of new dialysis centers a ‘Tier III’ priority, meaning that facilities must wait months or even years to receive CMS certification.   That's why I introduced a new bill that will provide under the Medicare program independent third party accreditation for dialysis centers. With this change to Medicare, folks on dialysis won’t have to feel the pinch of bureaucratic red tape preventing them from receiving this necessary medical treatment.  http://www.wibw.com/content/news/Kansas-rep-introduces-bill-to-get-new-dialysis-facilities-open-433024783.html

Tonight, my bill (H.R. 1541) to authorize the donation of the Fort Scott, Kan., Civil War era blockhouse known as Lunette Blair to the National Park Service at the Fort Scott National Historic Site passed the House of Representatives with strong bipartisan support. As this bill makes its way to the Senate, I urge my colleagues to bring this legislation to the floor so that we can get it to the President’s desk quickly.

Bipartisanship is about being willing to reach a hand across the aisle to find common ground. I am proud to partner with several of my Democratic colleagues in the House to find common ground and move legislation forward that will help Kansans and our country. Please read the article below to learn more about my latest efforts. http://www.newspressnow.com/news/local_news/jenkins-pushes-forward-on-bipartisan-bills/article_3e33278f-4a9f-51d9-9de4-7dd176a5a454.html

Today, my bill, H.R. 3166, to provide independent accreditation for dialysis facilities passed the House Ways and Means Committee with strong bipartisan support and is now headed to the House floor. This commonsense change will help curb bureaucracy in our healthcare to ensure folks on dialysis can get the care they need close to home. I urge my colleagues to support me on this endeavor and bring this bill to a vote on the House floor.

Yesterday, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) proposed a rule to update payment rates and policy changes in 2018. One of the provisions in the proposed rule would provide regulatory relief to rural hospitals by placing a two-year moratorium on a burdensome CMS rule requiring direct supervision of outpatient therapy services in rural and critical access hospitals.   Rural and critical access hospitals are the lifeblood of small farming communities across Kansas. CMS’s proposal to delay its direct supervision rule is a great step, but a permanent fix is still needed. That's why I introduced a bill that will permanently end CMS’s direct supervision rule. Protecting access to health care for our farmers, ranchers, and small town Kansans is crucial. I will continue working to repeal burdensome regulations on our rural and critical access hospitals to ensure their continued presence and vitality throughout Kansas.

Last week, the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) passed the House of Representatives with strong bipartisan support. This important legislation will provide crucial funding as we rebuild our military and restore it to its premier position as a leader among free nations. Additionally, our troops will receive a well-deserved pay raise – the largest in eight years. With increased dollars for our military bases, troop salaries, additional personnel, and missile defense spending, our troops will be equipped with the tools and resources they need to swiftly and safely carry out their missions. I applaud the passage of the NDAA, and I am proud to support our men and women in uniform who defend our freedom.
Please join me in praying for Senator John McCain and his family during this difficult time. He is a strong and resilient fighter who will overcome this battle.
Nothing makes me happier than meeting with Kansans while I’m working in Washington. Thank you to all of the Sunflower State folks who came by this week!

Please join me in wishing my good friend, Senator Bob Dole, a very happy birthday!! He is a dear friend and someone I consider to be the ultimate embodiment of a true Kansan. Thank you for your service to our great country and I wish you all the best!

Last week, I partnered with Congresswoman Doris Matsui (CA-D) to introduce H.R. 3331, to encourage the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) to create a demonstration project to help behavioral health IT providers purchase and implement Electronic Health Record (EHR) software for their patients. I look forward to working with Congresswoman Matsui, and anxiously anticipate the day that this important EHR software is available to health IT providers so they can better serve their patients.

Today, I joined Senator Pat Roberts in introducing legislation to award former Kansas U.S. Senator Robert J. Dole the Congressional Gold Medal in “recognition for his service to the nation as a soldier, legislator and statesman.”   As a World War II veteran, public servant and prolific role model, Senator Dole is certainly deserving of the Congressional Gold Medal. He spent his entire life serving Kansans and this great country. I look forward to getting this bill through Congress and to the President’s desk.

Today, my bill to provide independent accreditation for dialysis facilities passed the House of Representatives as part of the Medicare Part B Improvement Act of 2017. I am pleased to see this legislation passed with bipartisan support and is now headed to the United States Senate. I urge my colleagues to support this commonsense legislation as it will help folks get the care they desperately need.
It was great to meet and speak with so many Kansans this week in Washington. We had great conversations on several issues, such as the upcoming farm bill. Thanks for stopping by!

Recently, I joined Congressman Mike Thompson (CA-D) in introducing H.R. 3447, the Furthering Access to Coordinated Treatment for Seniors (FACTS) Act. The FACTS Act directs the Department on Health and Human Services (HHS) to establish a process by which Medicare Part D plans can request drug claims data to promote appropriate use of medications. This bipartisan legislation will help to save taxpayers money, and will improve the health and lives of seniors across the country. Learn more about this legislation by clicking the link below.

This is a promising step toward our goal of awarding a Congressional Gold Medal to Senator Dole. With 100 Senators as cosponsors, it is a remarkable sign of the depth of respect and support for Senator Dole. I applaud Senator Pat Roberts on this effort; he truly went above and beyond. Now, I encourage my House colleagues to join me in this bipartisan effort so that we can get this legislation to the President’s desk.

It was so great touring the Fort Scott National Historic Site, National Park Service. This Site depicts the important story of Fort Scott's role in nineteenth-century America. It serves as a physical snapshot of the “pioneer days” of westward migration of a young republic—from its initial construction 175 years ago. Thank you for such a great time!

This week, I had the opportunity to tour the Walmart Training Academy in Pittsburg. It was great meeting and speaking to so many Kansans and learning more about the academy. Thank you for the great tour!

I stopped by White Star Machinery & Supply of Topeka this week to discuss issues important to the construction equipment industry. We talked a lot about infrastructure and the need for tax reform. Afterwards, I toured the site and took some of their machines out for a spin.
Kansans know very well that I don't condone any form of hate or violence. White supremacy is a blight on our nation. The bigotry we saw this weekend has no place in America.

This morning in Leavenworth, I helped deliver some Meals on Wheels to folks in the area. I always enjoy this opportunity as I get to meet so many Kansans and help raise awareness for the program. Then I stopped by the VA campus to tour the recent renovations of the 130-year-old mess hall and other historic buildings. I always enjoy visiting Leavenworth, and I'm looking forward to my next visit soon!

Mr. President:  White supremacy, Nazis, and the KKK are a blight on our nation. Equal blame is not correct and racism should not be ignored.  When you use words that excuse their views it only fuels their hatred, further divides our nation, and tarnishes the sacred office you hold. For generations, Americans have fought and gone to war to stomp out ideologies like this. We must not turn our back on their sacrifice. Now is the time for all us to come together as Americans and help put an end to this bigotry.

Awful news in Barcelona. Please join me in sending prayers and thoughts to the victims and their families of this terror attack. Thankful for the courageous first-responders for quickly getting to the scene. I will continue to monitor this situation as more news develops.
If you are interested in viewing today's solar eclipse, check out NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Facebook page below for more information.
I had a stellar time viewing the Solar Eclipse in Atchison today. Such a cool experience!

As the anniversary of September 11th quickly approaches, we are reminded that Al-Qaeda, ISIS, and other terrorist groups, must not have any safe havens in this world. Destroying groups that plot to kill Americans is a necessity for our nation's security. I respect the President's decision, with the advice of our military leaders, to refocus our Afghanistan strategy based on conditions on the ground – not arbitrary timelines – which will give our commanders the flexibility they need to win and get out. With Secretary of Defense Mattis' strong leadership, I believe we can carry out the mission effectively. In the coming weeks, I look forward to reviewing the details of this strategy while listening to Kansan's thoughts on this important issue.

Mental Health First Aid has been one of my top priorities since coming to Congress. I have introduced and championed the Mental Health First Aid Act, which passed the House with strong bipartisan support and eventually was signed in to law. This important training helps law enforcement agents, first responders and others better identify and aid people in need before tragedy strikes. By building a stronger community, we can extend our mental health safety net in America to help and protect tens of millions of people.

Please join me in praying for all those affected by Hurricane Harvey. This storm has been heartbreaking to watch, and I am very thankful to the courageous first-responders and community leaders who are working hard to help folks in the area. If you are looking for ways to help, please read the following article below.

I am very proud to see Kansans and Missourians come together to help folks affected by Hurricane Harvey. This storm has been very brutal, and Texas is going to need all the help they can get. I know these volunteers will make us all proud!
Thank you to all the incredible workers in Kansas and across America whose hard-work, dedication and devotion helped build this great nation. Wishing everyone a happy and safe Labor Day!

According to the House Majority Leader’s Weekly schedule, legislation authored by myself and Senator Pat Roberts to award former Kansas U.S. Senator Robert J. Dole with the Congressional Gold Medal is headed to the House floor for a vote this upcoming week.  I am very pleased to see the House is acting quickly to bring this legislation up for a vote. Senator Dole has spent his life serving this great country, I could not think of a more deserving person to be honored with the Congressional Gold Medal. I look forward to passing this legislation with strong bipartisan support and getting it to the President’s desk.

Last night, legislation authored by myself and Senator Pat Roberts to award former Kansas U.S. Senator Robert J. Dole with the Congressional Gold Medal passed the House of Representatives with strong, bipartisan support. I am very pleased to see this legislation pass the House with support from Republicans and Democrats. In Congress, Senator Dole was known for reaching across the aisle, and I know he must be very proud to see this strong showing of unity. Now, I urge the President to sign this legislation so that we can honor this great American.

Disaster relief funding should not have been linked to a short term funding fix and a debt limit increase. Earlier this week, I supported a funding bill to help Texans rebuild and recover, but I was elected by Kansans to help get our national debt under control and this bill only makes the problem worse. Make no mistake, I stand with Texas but I believe this could have been handled differently – one vote on disaster relief and a separate vote on the continuing resolution and debt limit increase that included spending reforms. The people of Eastern Kansas elected me to Congress to help lower our national debt, not to keep Washington’s spending on auto-pilot.

Each year as the Representative of Kansas' 2nd District in the U.S House of Representatives, I have the privilege of nominating a select group of Kansans to the U.S. Service Academies. If you or someone you know is interested, please use the link below to my website for more information.

Today marks the 16th anniversary of the September 11th attacks, a day we will never forget. As I reflect on that morning, I can still vividly remember where I was when the attacks occurred, the sights I saw on TV and the many feelings I felt. It is a day that forever changed the course of our nation.    On this somber occasion, I invite my fellow Kansans to join me in honoring the victims, the survivors, their families and friends and the heroism and bravery of our first-responders. Additionally,  let us also honor our men and women in uniform who remain spread across the globe sacrificing each day, so that we may maintain our peace and freedom here at home.

To help make life easier for American families and businesses, Congress has embarked on an effort to accomplish comprehensive tax reform for the first time since 1986. We plan to lower tax rates for families and businesses, simplify a complex and burdensome code for filers, and encourage investment. We believe that these principles will unburden American taxpayers and help spur economic growth. But we can't accomplish this goal without your help. Please click on the link below and fill out the questionnaire so we can ensure your voice is heard in Congress.

Last night, North Korea fired a ballistic missile over the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido. This kind of brazen and aggressive “showboating” against one of our allies cannot continue. The United Nations should take immediate additional actions against North Korea.
Please join me in sending prayers to all those affected by today's terrorist attack in London. Our allies will not be intimidated by these cowardly attacks.

Yesterday, President Trump signed legislation authored by myself and Senator Pat Roberts to award former Kansas U.S. Senator Robert J. Dole with the Congressional Gold Medal.  This is a much overdue honor that could not have been accomplished without the great work of Senator Roberts and our entire Kansas Congressional delegation. Senator Dole has spent his life serving the state of Kansas and our country – helping veterans and combatting child hunger and poverty. I cannot think of anyone more deserving of a Congressional Gold Medal than the Senator. I am pleased the President quickly approved this legislation, and I look forward to the presentation of this elite award in the near future.

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to stop by the Topeka Zoo to visit the Camp Cowabunga exhibit. This exhibit  is going to be phenomenal and a real gift to the Topeka community. I'm looking forward to seeing it open and the excitement surrounding it!
L'Shanah Tova! Wishing everyone celebrating #RoshHashanah a sweet, healthy and happy New Year.

I had a lot of great visits throughout the Second District of Kansas this past week. I stopped by Helping Hands Humane Society, Head Start in Ottawa, Midwest Minerals in Parsons and spoke with AP Government Class students at Leavenworth High School along with several other meetings. It was great meeting so many Kansans and listening to their thoughts on several important issues. Thank you all for these great opportunities!

The last time our tax code was reformed was in 1986.  The economy has changed drastically since then and our severely inefficient, bloated and complicated tax code is harming American families.  I have been working for several years now to reform our broken tax code, to make it simpler and fairer.   This framework will serve as an outline as Congress takes an important step to reform our broken tax code and replace it with a simpler and fairer code. One that lowers rates for individuals and families so they save time and money doing their taxes and keep more of their hard-earned money. A tax code that helps jumpstart our economy and creates more opportunities for all Americans.  While some may try to compare this tax reform framework to what was tried in Kansas, the truth is these two reforms could not be more different. Under our framework, everyone pays a lower rate. In terms of pass-through businesses, Congress will lower the rate to 25%, not 0%. Our approach will actually lessen the tax avoidance and simultaneously bring American companies firmly in line with our global competitors.  There is a lot of information to digest in our tax reform framework, and I would recommend everyone read it for themselves. I look forward to a discussion with Kansans regarding this opportunity to reform our tax code for the first time in 31 years, and will certainly share their thoughts with my colleagues in Congress.
This week, I had the honor of welcoming some of Kansas' heroes to Washington, D.C. as they arrived on their Honor Flight. Thank you for your service to our great country!

My prayers are with all of those affected by the shootings in Lawrence and Las Vegas this weekend. Be sure to hug your loved ones extra tight today.  As for the shooting in Lawrence, if you witnessed anything that night, please be sure to contact the Lawrence Police Department at (785) 832-7509 or Crime Stoppers of Lawrence and Douglas County at (785) 843-TIPS. Tips made to Crime Stoppers may remain anonymous.

While I’m a strong supporter of our Second Amendment, when you can modify a legal semi-automatic rifle and make it function like an illegal fully automatic rifle – something isn’t right. I believe we should close the regulatory loophole that allows bump stocks and other devices like it.

Recently, I joined Congressman Dave Loebsack (IA-D) in sending a letter to Acting Secretary of Health and Human Services Don Wright to permanently prevent Medicare’s enforcement of unreasonable and inflexible direct supervision rules for outpatient therapy services at Critical Access Hospitals (CAHs) and other small, rural hospitals.  Permanently preventing the “direct supervision” rule will help CAHs and other rural hospitals plan for the future and focus more on their patients. I will continue working to repeal burdensome regulations on our rural and critical access hospitals to ensure their continued presence and vitality throughout Kansas.

Fixing our broken tax code is a foundational step to building a healthy economy, creating more jobs and ensuring more take home pay for hardworking Americans.  To that end, Congressional Republicans are working to reform our federal tax code – which today includes more than 70,000 pages of laws and regulations – to make it fairer and simpler.   As a member of the House representing Kansas, and as a member of the House Ways and Means Committee, I am often asked to explain the differences between Kansas’ tax reform and Washington’s tax reform. Before I begin to dispel the myths, I would ask that you please read the eight page framework – eight pages that lay out our vision for tax reform which can be found in the comment section.  In the coming weeks, as Congress continues to reform our broken tax code, I encourage everyone to read our framework – in its entirety – to better understand our policies and agenda. Simply stating that Washington’s tax reform is the exact same thing as Kansas’ tax reform is entirely incorrect. We learned from Kansas' missteps and took steps to correct them - because you, the taxpayer, deserve the best.
As tax reform continues to be front and center in Congress, I stopped by Ralph Hipp’s Red Couch Show on WIBW to discuss our proposed tax framework.

I cannot believe the Kansas City Star ran this grossly inaccurate column. The analysis and most of the facts are based on a 2016 analysis on a proposal from then candidate Trump. Our tax reform framework came out last month. As in September of 2017. The principles in it were agreed to by House and Senate leadership and the White House, but the KC Star is good with running with the plan circa fall 2016. Makes sense. Further, this editorial makes it seem that Congress is only cutting the top corporate and individual rates. Which is simply untrue and never has been. Just the other day, Speaker Ryan stated that we are keeping a 4th bracket to ensure our highest-income earners don’t get a rate cut. But you won’t find that in this column because, you know, why use information from last week when you have that trusty analysis from 2016. This entire editorial is based off of wrong information, but don’t hold your breath for a correction.

Awful news coming out of New York City. My thoughts and prayers are with the victims and their loved ones of this cowardly attack. I am very grateful for the brave first-responders who quickly reached the scene and secured the area.

Today, the Ways and Means Committee, of which I am a member, released the House tax reform bill.   This tax reform legislation shares our goals of ensuring that rates are cut for lower and middle income Americans, simplifying the tax system, and expanding American competition within the global economy.  However, now that this bill has been released, I would encourage everyone to read it before falsely stating this tax reform legislation is the same thing as the 2012 Kansas tax cut package. While Kansas took the pass-through rate to 0%, we are dropping the rate to 25% along with implementing strong safeguards to prevent the type of tax avoidance that was possible in the Kansas plan. Specifically, this tax plan only allows a pass-through business to claim 30% of their income at the lower 25% rate, and the other 70% of their income remains at the top individual tax rate. Further, it calls for pass-through entities that are considered ‘services businesses’ to be taxed at the higher income rate level, because their income is considered wages.    Lastly, it is important to state that this is not the final version of the tax reform bill. This introduction starts the legislative process as the Ways and Means Committee will meet next week to debate the bill and then send it to the House floor for full debate. In the meantime, I encourage everyone to read the legislation and contact my office with your thoughts so I can best represent you in Congress.
Praying for the victims, their loved ones and the Sutherland Springs community tonight. Thankful for the local first-responders for their brave actions to help secure the area.

RIGHT NOW: Committee on Ways and Means is beginning our work to reform the broken tax code. This is just the beginning, but I am looking forward to this great opportunity. Click the link below to watch the hearing.

The dependent care assistance program is a real tax benefit for middle-class families. This is something that I advocated for and I am pleased it has been extended for five years in our bill. As a working parent, I remember the difficulties of balancing work and family life and more relief is always needed. This, along with other provisions in this bill, gives hard-working families a break, and it helps make our tax code fairer.

It is my sincere hope that on this Veterans Day, we can come together to honor and reflect upon the sacrifices of those who have and continue to serve our country, especially all of the men and women who have given the ultimate sacrifice and laid down their lives in defense of this great nation. Thank you for your service!

As a CPA, reforming our tax code has been a priority of mine during my service in Congress. Our current tax code is broken and I’ve heard from Kansans who are frustrated with the status quo.    While I continue to work on improving this legislation, I am pleased this bill has passed the Ways and Means Committee and is now headed to the House floor for further debate. In the coming weeks, as this legislation winds its way through the legislative process, I look forward to meeting and speaking with Kansans on tax reform and sharing their views with my colleagues. Our tax code has not been updated in roughly 30 years. It is imperative that we get this accomplished.

As events play out on the international stage, we continually see America’s need for a strong national defense. Consequently, it is necessary that Congress provide the financial resources to allow the Department of Defense to carry out their mission. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2018, passed today by the House, authorizes $634.2 billion for the use of national defense requirements with an additional $65.7 billion allocated towards fighting the Global War on Terror. The bill funds a 2.4% military pay raise in the next fiscal year (the largest for our troops in 8 years), maintains the prohibitions on transferring detainees from Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and reaffirms deterrence commitments to Japan and South Korea. I applaud the passage of the NDAA, and I am proud to support our men and women in uniform who defend our freedom.

ATTENTION: I am pleased to announce that my 8th annual jobs fair will be held in Topeka on Friday, November 17th from 10am to 1pm at the Kansas Expocentre, Agriculture Hall. The jobs fair is free and open to the public. We already have dozens of businesses signed up to attend from a wide range of industries including health care, manufacturing, hospitality and many more. I am anticipating another great turnout this year and looking forward to seeing everyone on Friday. For more information, please click the link below.

After several years of working on tax reform, I am pleased to see the House has passed legislation that will permanently lower rates for hard-working individuals, families and businesses, along with preserving and expanding many popular tax provisions that will help folks keep more of their hard-earned money. We are one step closer to rewriting our broken tax code, one that will be fairer and simpler for all. Now, the Senate is beginning work on their tax reform legislation and I will continue to monitor it as it makes its way through the legislative process. Tax reform has a long way to go before coming law, so I encourage Kansans to read both pieces of legislation and contact my office with any thoughts – I always appreciate it.

HAPPENING NOW: My annual jobs fair in Topeka is underway! It's located in Agriculture Hall at the Kansas Expocentre in Topeka until 1pm CST. More information can be found here: https://lynnjenkins.house.gov/2017-jobs-fair

Yesterday, I had the opportunity to tour Topeka YMCA’s Kuehne Branch and learn about their new changes. This specific branch has a partnership with the Department of Veterans Affairs and is dedicated to our military branches. They provide lower rates to veteran’s and have rooms dedicated to specific military branches. It was great to tour this facility with Topeka YMCA President and CEO John Mugler and meet several of his caring staff along the way.

Rural health care services are one of the most essential aspects to the survival and continued success of small towns across Kansas as well as the rest of the country. Access to quality health care services determines whether Kansans can remain in the communities they call home and, crucially, whether their children will stay or return to those communities and raise families of their own; adding future generations to the rural way of life. Growing up in Holton, I know with certainty the challenges our rural hospitals and health providers face day in and day out and I recognize Congress’s commitment to ensuring these kinds of services endure, either through Medicare or other federal support mechanisms.  That is why on November 16th—National Rural Health Day—I introduced a resolution in the House of Representatives, as joined by a group of critical lawmakers both Democrat and Republican, highlighting and celebrating the important roles health care providers and hospitals play in rural areas. As a nation, we must continue to support our critical health care systems, especially in small town America.

This Thanksgiving, I want to reflect on some of the things I am most grateful for.  I am thankful for fields of Kansas sunflowers and for triple-scoop chocolate ice cream cones! I am thankful to have the honor to live in and represent a state that is known around the country for its unfailing kindness. I am thankful to our farmers and ranchers who raise the food we put on our tables this holiday season and I am thankful for the organizations which work toward a Thanksgiving where no family goes hungry.  I am very blessed that I was able to be home in Kansas with my loved ones to celebrate and give thanks. As we kick-off another busy holiday season, let us keep in mind those who are unable to be with their families this year, especially our servicemen and women who work each day to keep Americans and our freedoms safe.  I hope you had a very Happy Thanksgiving!

I don’t care who you are, what you do, where you work, or what you believe, sexual harassment does not belong in our society.  That’s why I cosponsored H.Res. 630 which passed the House today with my support which will require all Members and employees of the House of Representatives to complete sexual harassment and workplace rights training at the start of each session of Congress. This new legislation works to ensure that Congressional employees are safe and respected. There is much more work to be done, but this is a good start.
Absolutely shocked by the #KateSteinle verdict. Justice was not served for Kate. Keeping her family in my prayers.

I am pleased to see the Senate has acted on tax reform and passed their legislation. Now, the House will vote to go to Conference on Monday and we can continue our work on re-writing our broken tax code. There are many differences between the House and Senate legislation, such as the pass-through business tax rate, the corporate tax rate, and the child tax credit, that will need to be resolved.  With the many important discussions that will occur in the coming weeks, I encourage you to contact my office with your ideas and concerns. I will be sure to share your thoughts with my colleagues as we work to let Americans keep more of their money and make our tax code fairer and simpler for all.

Recently, with my urging, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) placed a two year suspension on a burdensome rule that requires hospitals to perform most outpatient therapeutic services under the “direct supervision” of a physician or qualified non-physician practitioner. However, while it covered 2018 and 2019, the moratorium failed to include calendar year 2017, leaving hospitals exposed for potential regulatory action.  To help our rural communities, I introduced H.R. 4520 to provide regulatory relief to rural hospitals for 2017 by placing a one-year moratorium on this burdensome CMS rule. The moratorium has been extended numerous times in recent years covering all prior years since the regulation was put into place.  While I feel strongly that a permanent solution here would be a far better choice for the lifeblood of Kansas communities by alleviating barriers to healthcare access, H.R.4520 will provide crucial stopgap regulatory certainty to small town hospitals for 2017. I will continue working to repeal burdensome regulations on our rural and critical access hospitals to ensure their continued presence and vitality throughout Kansas.
For years, Congress has overwhelmingly agreed that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel. This decision confirms what we already knew, that the United States stands with our allies and friends.
Please join me in remembering all of those who lost their lives in the attack at Pearl Harbor. The Greatest Generation continues to inspire us today. Thank you for your service.

Health Savings Accounts (HSA) and Flexible Spending Accounts (FSA) are the bedrock of consumer choice. They allow individuals to spend their healthcare dollars towards the specific needs of their families. My legislation would remove Obamacare’s harmful prohibition on the use of HSAs and FSAs for basic, over-the-counter needs of thousands of Kansans. I look forward to continuing to work on the Ways and Means committee to provide meaningful, incremental improvements to our health care system.
BREAKING NEWS: House passes historic tax reform. The bill now heads to President Trump's desk for signature.

On January 17th, leaders of the U.S. House and Senate will present a Congressional Gold Medal to former Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole in recognition of his service to the nation as a solider, legislator, and statesman. Senator Dole was awarded two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star for his brave service during World War II. Now he will be awarded a Congressional Gold Medal, the highest civilian honor.  I can think of no more deserving recipient than my friend, Senator Bob Dole. I look forward to celebrating and honoring this great man in January.

Because of the tax cuts and jobs act, which President Trump just signed into law, the average family of 4 in the 2nd district will see their Federal income tax bill nearly cut in half, which will be an extra $2,279 in their pocket. The pundits on T.V. making 6 figure incomes may not think this is a lot of money but for folks in my district this is real relief.

As 2017 comes to a close and I soon begin my last year in Congress, much has changed over the years. One thing that remains unchanged is how much I appreciate Kansans' trust in me to be their voice in government.
